title: The Quiet Witness
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock sat on his porch, whittling a piece of wood into what might eventually become a bird. Or a boat. Or just a pile of wood shavings. A young woman, barely out of her teens, walked hesitantly up his path. Sarah had been sent by the church, a little unsure but willing. The church had started a program, 'Share Your Story, Share His Love,' aimed at connecting with the community. Sarah, bright-eyed and eager, was their first volunteer. 

"Afternoon, Mr. Hemlock," she said, her voice a little too loud. He looked up, his eyes crinkling at the corners. "Just Hemlock, dear. Everyone calls me Hemlock." He gestured to a rickety chair. "Have a seat. Don't get many visitors these days."

Sarah sat, clutching a small, worn Bible. "The church sent me. We're trying to… well, to connect with folks. Share our faith." Hemlock chuckled. "Faith, eh? A lot of folks lost theirs a long time ago." He carved a bit more wood. "What makes you think I'd be interested?"

Sarah took a breath. "I don't know, sir. But I believe everyone needs to hear about Jesus. About the hope He offers, even when things are tough." She spoke about her own struggles, a sick mother, a difficult job. Then, she shared how her faith gave her strength. Hemlock listened, his expression unreadable. He didn't interrupt, didn't comment. He just whittled.

Finally, Sarah finished. "I'm not very good at this," she admitted, feeling defeated. Hemlock stopped whittling and looked at her, his eyes surprisingly kind. "You spoke from the heart, child. That's all that matters." He paused. "Tell you what. Come back next week. Maybe I'll have a story to share with you. Might not be about faith, but stories are important, too."

Sarah left, feeling a little less defeated. She hadn't converted Hemlock, hadn't even gotten a word of encouragement. But she had planted a seed. Evangelism isn't always about grand pronouncements or instant conversions. Sometimes, it's about showing up, listening, and planting a seed of hope in someone's heart. It's about being willing to share your story, and more importantly, willing to listen to theirs.
image_description: A weathered wooden porch with a rocking chair and potted plants, bathed in the warm afternoon sunlight.
insights: Sarah's approach, while perhaps hesitant, illustrates a key aspect of evangelism: relationship. 1 Peter 3:15 encourages us to 'always be prepared to give an answer to everyone who asks you to give the reason for the hope that you have. But do this with gentleness and respect.' Sarah's gentleness and respect, even in the face of Hemlock's initial skepticism, opened a door for future conversation. It's a reminder that genuine connection and authentic sharing are often more effective than forceful arguments.
prayer: Lord, help us to be bold in sharing Your love, but also gentle and respectful in our approach. Give us the wisdom to discern when to speak and when to listen. Remind us that even small acts of kindness and genuine connection can plant seeds of hope in the hearts of others. Help us to be faithful witnesses, trusting that You will bring the increase. Amen.
reflection: How can you cultivate a spirit of gentleness and respect in your evangelistic efforts? What are some practical ways you can build relationships with those who may be skeptical or resistant to the Gospel? How can you be more attentive to the stories and experiences of others, creating opportunities for meaningful connection?
